Description: Bone inlay; carved from animal-bone with polished surfaces; decorated with a stylised vine-scroll; original sawn edge at upper end and along the top, but broken along the tother two edges; pierced with a small circular rivet hole.
Curator's comments: This belongs to a distinctive class of object which probably begins in the Late Roman/Byzantine period and certainly continues into the early Islamic period. They are well known from Egypt, e.g. from excavations at Fustat (M. Kawatoko & Y. Shindo, 'Artifacts of the Medieval Islamic Period Excavated in al-Fustat, Egypt', Waseda University 2010, p.9, col. pl. 11.15).
Acquisition name: Transferred from: Victoria and Albert Museum
Additional IDs: Previous owner/ex-collection number: A.98-1929 (V&A number (partly illegible))
